question: You feeling any better?
answer: A little bit.

question: Guess what.
answer: What?

question: Your grandfather's here.
answer: Mom, can't you tell him that I'm sick?

question: You are sick, that's why he's here.
answer: He'll pinch my cheek. I hate that.

question: I brought you a special present.
answer: What is it?

question: Open it up.
answer: A book?

question: That's right. When I was your age, television was called books. And this is a special book. It was the book my father used to read to me when I was sick, and I used to read it to your father. And today, I'm gonna read it to you.
answer: Has it got any sports in it?

question: Are you kidding? Fencing. Fighting. Torture. Revenge. Giants. Monsters. Chases. Escapes. True love. Miracles.
answer: It doesn't sound too bad. I'll try and stay awake.

question: Oh. Well, thank you very much. It's very nice of you. Your vote of confidence is overwhelming. All right. The Princess Bride, by S. Morgenstern. Chapter One. Buttercup was raised on a small farm in the country of Florin. Her favorite pastimes were riding her horse and tormenting the farm boy that worked there. His name was Westley, but she never called him that. Isn't that a wonderful beginning?
answer: Yeah. It's really good.

question: -hold it, hold it- What is this? Are you trying to trick me? -- Where's the sports? -- Is this a kissing book?
answer: -- wait, just wait --

question: -- well, when does it get good?
answer: Keep your shirt on. Let me read. Westley had no money for marriage. So he packed his few belongings and left the farm to seek his fortune across the sea. It was a very emotional time for Buttercup --

question: I fear I'll never see you again.
answer: Of course you will.

question: But what if something happens to you?
answer: Hear this now

question: But how can you be sure?
answer: This is true love. You think this happens every day?

question: It's fabric from the uniform of an Army officer of Guilder.
answer: Who's Guilder?

question: The country across the sea. The sworn enemy of Florin. Go! Once the horse reaches the castle, the fabric will make the Prince suspect the Guilderians have abducted his love. When he finds her body dead on the Guilder frontier, his suspicions will be totally confirmed.
answer: You never said anything about killing anyone.

question: I've hired you to help me start a war. That's a prestigious line of work with a long and glorious tradition.
answer: I just don't think it's right, killing an innocent girl.

question: That Vizzini, he can fuss.
answer: ... fuss ... fuss ... I think he likes to scream at us.

question: Probably he means no harm.
answer: He's really very short on charm.

question: Oh, you've a great gift for rhyme.
answer: Yes, some of the time.

question: Of all the necks on this boat, Highness, the one you should be worrying about is your own. Stop doing that. We can all relax, it's almost over-
answer: You're sure nobody's following us?

question: As I told you, it would be absolutely, totally, and in all other ways, inconceivable. No one in Guilder knows what we've done. And no one in Florin could have gotten here so fast. Out of curiosity, why do you ask?
answer: No reason. It's only, I just happened to look behind us, and something is there.

question: What? Probably some local fisherman out for a pleasure cruise at night through eel-infested waters. Go in, get after her!
answer: I don't swim.

question: She doesn't get eaten by the Eels at this time.
answer: What?

question: The Eel doesn't get her. I'm explaining to you because you looked nervous.
answer: Well, I wasn't nervous. Well, maybe I was a little bit concerned. But that's not the same thing.

question: Because I can stop now if you want.
answer: No. You could read a little bit more ... if you want.

question: Faster!
answer: I thought I was going faster.

question: You were supposed to be this colossus. You were this great, legendary thing. And yet he gains.
answer: Well, I'm carrying three people. And he's got only himself.

question: -- I do not accept excuses. I'm just going to have to find myself a new giant, that's all.
answer: Don't say that, Vizzini. Please.

question: Whoever he is, he's obviously seen us with the Princess, and must therefore die. You, carry her. We'll head straight for the Guilder frontier. Catch up when he's dead. If he falls, fine. If not, the sword.
answer: I want to duel him left-handed.

question: You know what a hurry we're in.
answer: Well, it's the only way I can be satisfied. If I use my right -- tch -- over too quickly.

question: walking away. Finally he goes back to cliff edge, starts to talk. It's instant death if the Man In Black falls, but neither gives that possibility much credence. This is our two heroes meeting. They don't know it yet; but that's what it is. Hello there. Slow going?
answer: Look, I don't mean to be rude, but this is not as easy as it looks. So I'd appreciate it if you wouldn't distract me.

question: Sorry.
answer: Thank you.

question: I do not suppose you could speed things up?
answer: If you're in such a hurry, you could lower a rope, or a tree branch, or find something useful to do.

question: I could do that. In fact, I've got some rope up here. But I do not think that you will accept my help, since I am only waiting around to kill you.
answer: That does put a damper on our relationship.

question: But I promise I will not kill you until you reach the top.
answer: That's very comforting. But I'm afraid you'll just have to wait.

question: I hate waiting. I could give you my word as a Spaniard.
answer: No good. I've known too many Spaniards.

question: You don't know any way you'll trust me?
answer: Nothing comes to mind.

question: I swear on the soul of my father, Domingo Montoya, you will reach the top alive.
answer: Throw me the rope.

question: He dashes to the giant rock the rope was originally tied to.
answer: as his grip loosens a moment, trying to cling to the side of the cliff.

question: now with a small coil of rope, hurries back to the edge and hurls it over -- straining, forcing his body away from the cliff edge and --
answer: rising through the early morning light, slowly, steadily, and as the cliff top at last comes within reach --

question: watching as the Man In Black crawls to safety, then looks to Inigo.
answer: Thank you.

question: We'll wait until you're ready.
answer: Again. Thank you.

question: I do not mean to pry, but you don't by any chance happen to have six fingers on your right hand?

question: My father was slaughtered by a sixfingered man. He was a great swordmaker, my father. And when the six-fingered man appeared and requested a special sword, my father took the job. He slaved a year before he was done.
answer: I have never seen its equal.

question: How old were you?
answer: I was eleven years old. When I was strong enough, I dedicated my life to the study of fencing. So the next time we meet, I will not fail. I will go up to the sixfingered man and say, "Hello, my name is Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die."

question: You've done nothing but study swordplay?

question: Well, I certainly hope you find him, someday.

question: Whether I am or not, you've been more than fair.

question: You seem a decent fellow. I hate to die.

question: I thought it fitting, considering the rocky terrain --

question: -- naturally -- --but I find Thibault cancels out Capo Ferro, don't you?

You are wonderful!

question: Thank you -- I've worked hard to become so.
answer: I admit it -- you are better than I am.

question: Then why are you smiling?
answer: Because I know something you don't know.

question: And what is that?
answer: I am not left-handed.

question: and the six-fingered sword is all but invisible now, as he increases his attack, then suddenly switches styles again.
answer: You're amazing!

question: I ought to be after twenty years.
answer: There's something I ought to tell you.

question: Tell me.
answer: I am not left-handed either.

question: staring in awe. Who are you?!
answer: No one of consequence.

question: I must know.
answer: Get used to disappointment.

question: Okay. moving like lightning, and he thrusts forward, slashes, darts back, all in almost a single movement and --

question: And there is never a move anyone makes he doesn't remember, and this time he blocks the slash, slashes out himself with the sixfingered sword. catching it again. And something terrible is written behind his eyes
answer: moving in for the end now, blocking everything, muzzling everything and

question: Give her to me. Catch up with us quickly.

question: Finish him, finish him. Your way.

question: Pick up one of those rocks, get behind the boulder, and in a few minutes, the Man in Black will come running around the bend. The minute his head is in view, hit it with the rock!

question: He moves into the mountain path. He has picked up another rock and holds it lightly. I did that on purpose. I don't have to miss.

question: We face each other as God intended. Sportsmanlike. No tricks, no weapons, skill against skill alone.

question: I could kill you now.

question: It's not my fault being the biggest and the strongest. I don't even exercise.

question: I just want you to feel you're doing well. I hate for people to die embarrassed. as he jumps forward with stunning speed for anyone his size and reaches for the Man In Black who drops to his knees, spins loose, and slips between the Giant's legs. You're quick.

question: Why do you wear a mask? Were you burned by acid, or something like that?

question: There was a mighty duel -- it ranged all over. They were both masters.
answer: Who won? How did it end?

question: The loser ran off alone. The winner followed those footprints toward Guilder!

question: The loser is nothing. -- Only the Princess matters -- -- clearly this was all planned by warriors of Guilder. We must be ready for whatever lies ahead.
answer: Could this be a trap?

question: So, it is down to you. And it is down to me. If you wish her dead, by all means keep moving forward.

question: -- there's nothing to explain. You're trying to kidnap what I've rightfully stolen.
answer: Perhaps an arrangement can be reached.

question: But if there can be no arrangement, then we are at an impasse.
answer: I'm afraid so -- I can't compete with you physically. And you're no match for my brains.

question: You're that smart?
answer: Let me put it this way

question: Yes.
answer: Morons.

question: Really? In that case, I challenge you to a battle of wits.
answer: For the Princess? To the death? I accept.

question: Good. Then pour the wine. Inhale this, but do not touch.
answer: I smell nothing.

question: What you do not smell is called iocane powder. It is odorless, tasteless, dissolves instantly in liquid, and is among the more deadlier poisons known to man.
answer: Hmm. watching excitedly as the Man In Black takes the goblets, turns his back. A moment later, he turns again, faces Vizzini, drops the iocane packet. It is now empty.

question: All right
answer: But it's so simple. All I have to do is divine from what I know of you. Are you the sort of man who would put the poison into his own goblet, or his enemy's? Now, a clever man would put the poison into his own goblet, because he would know that only a great fool would reach for what he was given. I'm not a great fool, so I can clearly not choose the wine in front of you. But you must have known I was not a great fool; you would have counted on it, so I can clearly not choose the wine in front of me.

question: You've made your decision then7
answer: Not remotely. Because iocane comes from Australia, as everyone knows. And Australia is entirely peopled with criminals. And criminals are used to having people not trust them, as you are not trusted by me. So I can clearly not choose the wine in front of you.

question: Truly, you have a dizzying intellect.
answer: Wait till I get going! Where was I?

question: Australia.
answer: Yes -- Australia, and you must have suspected I would have known the powder's origin, so I can clearly not choose the wine in front of me.

question: You're just stalling now.
answer: You'd like to think that, wouldn't you? You've beaten my giant, which means you're exceptionally strong. So, you could have put the poison in your own goblet, trusting on your strength to save you. So I can clearly not choose the wine in front of you. But, you've also bested my Spaniard which means you must have studied. And in studying, you must have learned that man is mortal so you would have put the poison as far from yourself as possible, so I can clearly not choose the wine in front of me.

question: You're trying to trick me into giving away something -- it won't work --
answer: It has worked -- you've given everything away -- I know where the poison is.

question: Then make your choice.
answer: I will. And I choose -- -- what in the world can that be?

question: What? Where? I don't see anything.
answer: busily switching the goblets while the Man In Black has his head turned. Oh, well, I-I could have sworn I saw something. No matter.

question: What's so funny?
answer: I'll tell you in a minute. First, let's drink -- me from my glass, and you from yours.

question: You guessed wrong.
answer: You only think I guessed wrong -- -- that's what's so funny! I switched glasses when your back was turned. You fool.

question: Catch your breath.
answer: If you'll release me ... whatever you ask for ransom ... you'll get it, I promise you...

question: And what is that worth, the promise of a woman? You're very funny, Highness.
answer: I was giving you a chance. No matter where you take me ... there's no greater hunter than Prince Humperdinck. He could track a falcon on a cloudy day. He can find you

question: You think your dearest love will save you?
answer: I never said he was my dearest love. And yes, he will save me. That I know.

question: You admit to me you do not love your fiance?
answer: He knows I do not love him.

question: "Are not capable of love" is what you mean.
answer: I have loved more deeply than a killer like yourself could ever dream.

question: being spun INTO CAMERA view, falling heavily as the Man In Black releases her. We are at the edge of an almost sheer ravine. The drop is sharp and severe. Below, the ravine floor is flat, but getting there would not be half the fun.
answer: Rest, Highness.

question: I know who you are -- your cruelty reveals everything. You're the Dread Pirate Roberts; admit it.
answer: With pride. What can I do for you?

question: You can die slowly cut into a thousand pieces.

question: It's possible; I kill a lot of people. Who was this love of yours? Another Prince, like this one, ugly, rich, and scabby?
answer: No. A farm boy. Poor. Poor and perfect, with eyes like the sea after a storm. And probably, if she did not hate Roberts so, there would be tears. On the high seas, your ship attacked, and the Dread Pirate Roberts never takes prisoners.

question: I can't afford to make exceptions. Once word leaks out that a pirate has gone soft, people begin to disobey you, and then it's nothing but work, work, work, all the time.
answer: You mock my pain!

question: Life is pain, Highness. Anyone who says differently is selling something. I remember this farm boy of yours, I think. This would be, what, five years ago? Does it bother you to hear?
answer: Nothing you can say will upset me.

question: He died well, that should please you. No bribe attempts or blubbering. He simply said, "Please. Please, I need to live." It was the "please" that caught my memory. You should bless me for destroying him before he found out what you really are.
answer: And what am I?

question: Faithfulness he talked of, madam. Your enduring faithfulness. Now, tell me truly. When you found out he was gone, did you get engaged to your prince that same hour, or did you wait a whole week out of respect for the dead?
answer: You mocked me once, never do it again -- I died that day! and while his attention is on the dust cloud, rising high, she pushes him with all the strength she has. You can die too, for all I care!!

question: bruised and torn, as Westley crawls slowly toward her.

question: Move? You're alive. If you want, I can fly.

question: Well ... you were dead.

question: I will never doubt again.
answer: There will never be a need.

question: Oh no. No, please.

question: They're kissing again, do we have to hear the kissing part?

question: Skip on to the Fire Swamp -- that sounded good.

question: Ha. Your pig fiance is too late. A few more steps and we'll be safe in the Fire Swamp.

question: Nonsense -- you're only saying that because no one ever has. It's not that bad. answer: You?

question: Well, one thing I will say. The Fire Swamp certainly does keep you on your toes. This will all soon be but a happy memory because Roberts' ship "Revenge" is anchored at the far end. And I, as you know, am Roberts.
answer: But how is that possible, since he's been marauding twenty years and you only left me five years ago?

question: I myself am often surprised at life's little quirks. You see, what I told you before about saying "please" was true. It intrigued Roberts, as did my descriptions of your beauty. Finally, Roberts decided something. He said, "All right, Westley, I've never had a valet. You can try it for tonight. I'll most likely kill you in the morning." Three years he said that. "Good night, Westley. Good work. Sleep well. I'll most likely kill you in the morning." It was a fine time for me. I was learning to fence, to fight, anything anyone would teach me. And Roberts and I eventually became friends. And then it happened.
answer: What? -- go on --

question: Well, Roberts had grown so rich, he wanted to retire. So he took me to his cabin and told me his secret. "I am not the Dread Pirate Roberts," he said. "My name is Ryan. I inherited this ship from the previous Dread Pirate Roberts, just as you will inherit it from me. The man I inherited it from was not the real Dread Pirate Roberts, either. His name was Cummerbund. The real Roberts has been retired fifteen years and living like a king in Patagonia." Then he explained the name was the important thing for inspiring the necessary fear. You see, no one would surrender to the Dread Pirate Westley. So we sailed ashore, took on an entirely new crew and he stayed aboard for awhile as first mate, all the time calling me Roberts. Once the crew believed, he left the ship and I have been Roberts ever since. Except, now that we're together, I shall retire and hand the name over to someone else. Is everything clear to you?
answer: placed against a tree. Westley is cleaning the lightning sand from her face. He hesitates, glances around and We'll never succeed -- we may as well die here.

question: No. No. We have already succeeded. I mean, what are the three terrors of the Fire Swamp? One, the flame spurts. No problem. There's a popping sound preceding each, we can avoid that. answer: Westley, what about the R.O.U.S.'s?

question: Rodents of Unusual Size? I don't think they exist...
answer: screaming and -- Westley!

question: jumping onto its back, and the R.0.U.S. is all over him now, sinking needle teeth into Westley's shoulder. with death close at hand, as a popping sound starts. He tries one desperate move, rolls into the sound -- with the R.0.U.S. pinned under him, and as the beast bursts into flame, it lets go and Westley rolls safely free, grabs his sword and exhaustedly stabs the R.0.U.S., which is trying to put itself out.
answer: relieved. We did it.

question: Now, was that so terrible?
answer: Surrender!

question: You mean you wish to surrender to me? Very well, I accept.
answer: I give you full marks for bravery --don't make yourself a fool.

question: Ah, but how will you capture us? We know the secrets of the Fire Swamp. We can live there quite happily for some time. So, whenever you feel like dying, feel free to visit.
answer: I tell you once again -- surrender!

question: staring after her. Rugen watches as his warriors bring Westley to him. The Count has a heavy sword and he holds it in his hand.
answer: Come, sir. We must get you to your ship.

question: We are men of action. Lies do not become us.

question: You have six fingers on your right hand -- someone was looking for you -- Where am I?
answer: The Pit of Despair. Don't even think -- -- don't even think about trying to escape. The chains are far too thick. And don't dream of being rescued either. The only way in is secret. And only the Prince, the Count, and I know how to get in and out.

question: Then I'm here till I die?
answer: Till they kill you. Yeah.

question: Then why bother curing me?
answer: The Prince and the Count always insist on everyone being healthy before they're broken.

question: So it's to be torture. I can cope with torture. You don't believe me?
answer: You survived the Fire Swamp. You must be very brave... ... but nobody withstands The Machine.

question: -- hold it. Hold it, Grandpa. You read that wrong. She doesn't marry Humperdinck, she marries Westley. I'm just sure of it. After all that Westley did for her, if she does not marry him, it wouldn't be fair.
answer: Well, who says life is fair? Where is that written? Life isn't always fair.

question: I'm telling you you're messing up the story, now get it right!
answer: Do you want me to go on with this?

question: Yes.
answer: All right, then. No more interruptions. ... at noon, she met her subjects again. This time as their Queen.

question: Your Princess is really a winning creature. A trifle simple, perhaps, but her appeal is undeniable.
answer: Oh, I know. The people are quite taken with her. It's odd, but when I hired Vizzini to have her murdered on our engagement day, I thought that was clever. But it's going to be so much more moving when I strangle her on our wedding night. Once Guilder is blamed, the nation will be truly outraged. They'll demand we go to war.

question: Now, where is that secret knot? It's impossible to find. Are you coming down into the Pit? Westley's got his strength back. I am starting him on The Machine tonight.
answer: Tyrone, you know how much I love watching you work. But, I've got my country's five hundredth anniversary to plan, my wedding to arrange, My wife to murder, and Guilder to frame for it. I'm swamped.

question: Of course. She will not be murdered. On the day of the wedding, I want the Thieves' Forest emptied and every inhabitant arrested.
answer: Many of the thieves will resist. My regular enforcers will be inadequate.

question: Form a Brute Squad then. I want the Thieves' Forest emptied before I wed.
answer: It won't be easy, Sire.

question: drunk as a skunk, sprawled in front of a hovel, a bottle of brandy in one hand, the six-fingered sword in the other. He looks dreadful. Unshaven, puffy-eyed, gaunt. This is where I am, and this is where I'll stay. I will not be moved. I do not budge. Keep your "Ho there." -- So did Vizzini -- when a job went wrong, you went back to the beginning. answer: Hello.

question: It's you.
answer: True! You don't look so good. You don't smell so good either.

question: Perhaps not. I feel fine.
answer: Yeah?

question: That's enough. That's enough! Where is this Rugen so I may kill him?
answer: He's with the Prince in the Castle. But the castle gate is guarded by thirty men.

question: How many could you handle?
answer: I don't think more than ten.

question: That leaves twenty for me. At my best, I could never defeat that many. I need Vizzini to plan. I have no gift for strategy.
answer: But Vizzini's dead.

question: No -- not Vizzini -- I need the Man in Black --

question: -- look, he bested you with strength, your greatness. He bested me with steel. He must have outthought Vizzini, and a man who can do that can plan my castle's onslaught any day. Let's go --
answer: -- where?

question: To find the Man in Black, obviously.
answer: But you don't know where he is.

question: Rise and report.
answer: The Thieves' Forest is emptied. Thirty men guard the castle gate.

question: Double it. My Princess must be safe.
answer: The gate has but one key, and I carry that.

question: staring at Humperdinck. You never sent the ships. Don't bother lying. It doesn't matter. Westley will come for me anyway.

question: Yes, I am a silly girl, for not having seen sooner that you were nothing but a coward with a heart full of fear.

question: Why not? You can't hurt me. Westley and I are joined by the bonds of love. And you cannot track that. Not with a thousand bloodhounds. And you cannot break it. Not with a thousand swords. You truly love each other, and so you might have been truly happy. Not one couple in a century has that chance, no matter what the storybooks say. question: The Man in Black?
answer: His true love is marrying another tonight, so who else has cause for Ultimate Suffering? Excuse me -- -- pardon me, it's important -- -- Fezzik, please --

question: Everybody ... MOVE!!

question: I'm sorry, Inigo. I didn't mean to jog him so hard. Inigo?
answer: He kneels, the sword held tight between his hands. Eyes closed, he faces the grove of trees, starts to talk, his voice low and strange. Father, I have failed you for twenty years. Now our misery can end. Somewhere ... somewhere close by is a man who can help us. I cannot find him alone. I need you. I need you to guide my sword. Please. Guide my sword. walking blind through the grove of trees. He moves to the Secret Knot, hesitates, then moves past it.

question: -- Grandpa, Grandpa -- wait -- -- wait -- what did FEZZIK mean, "He's dead?" I mean he didn't mean dead. Westley's only faking, right?

question: Who gets Humperdinck?

question: Who kills Prince Humperdinck? At the end, somebody's got to do it. Is it Inigo? Who?

question: You mean he wins? Jesus, Grandpa! What did you read me this thing for?

question: No! I'm okay. I'm okay. -- sit down. All right?
answer: Okay. All right, now, let's see. Where were we? Oh yes. In the Pit of Despair.

question: Well, we Montoyas have never taken defeat easily. Come along, Fezzik. Bring the body.
answer: The body?

question: Have you any money?
answer: I have a little.

question: You are the Brute Squad.
answer: We need a miracle. It's very important.

question: Look, I'm retired. And besides, why would you want someone the King's stinking son fired? I might kill whoever you wanted me to miracle.
answer: He's already dead.

question: He is, eh? I'll take a look. Bring him in. I've seen worse.
answer: Sir. Sir.

question: Hah?
answer: We're really in a terrible rush.

question: Don't rush me, sonny. You rush a miracle man, you get rotten miracles. You got money?
answer: Sixty-five.

question: Sheesh! I never worked for so little, except once, and that was a very noble cause.
answer: This is noble, sir. His wife is crippled. His children are on the brink of starvation.

question: Are you a rotten liar.
answer: I need him to help avenge my father, murdered these twenty years.

question: Your first story was better. Where's that bellows? He probably owes you money, huh? Well, I'll ask him.
answer: He's dead. He can't talk.

question: Look who knows so much. Well, it just so happens that your friend here is only mostly dead. There's a big difference between mostly dead and all dead. Please open his mouth. Now, mostly dead is slightly alive. Now, all dead...well, with all dead, there's usually only one thing that you can do.
answer: What's that?

question: Sonny, true love is the greatest thing in the world. Except for a nice MLT, a mutton, lettuce and tomato sandwich, where the mutton is nice and lean and the tomato is ripe. They're so perky, I love that. But that's not what he said. He distinctly said "to blave." And, as we all know, "to blave" means "to bluff." So you're probably playing cards, and he cheated -- get back, witch --
answer: I'm not a witch, I'm your wife. But after what you just said, I'm not even sure I want to be that anymore.

question: You never had it so good.
answer: "True love." He said, "true love," Max. My God --

question: Don't say another word, Valerie.
answer: He's afraid. Ever since Prince Humperdinck fired him, his confidence is shattered.

question: Why'd you say that name -- you promised me that you would never say that name --
answer: What, Humperdinck? Humperdinck. Humperdinck. Ooo-ooo, Humperdinck

question: I'm not listening.
answer: A life expiring and you don't have the decency to say why you won't help --

question: Nobody's hearing nothing!
answer: Humperdinck. Humperdinck! Humperdinck!

question: Okay.
answer: Bye-bye, boys.

question: Have fun storming the castle.
answer: Think it'll work?

question: It would take a miracle. Bye!
answer: Bye.

question: Inigo -- there's more than thirty --
answer: What's the difference? We've got him. Help me here. We'll have to force feed him.

question: Has it been fifteen minutes?
answer: We can't wait -- the wedding's in half an hour and we must strike in the hustle and the bustle beforehand. Tilt his head back. Open his mouth.

question: How long do we have to wait before we know if the miracle works?
answer: Pill in hand, he drops it into Westley's mouth. Your guess is as good as mine --

question: I've always been a quick healer. What are our liabilities?
answer: There is but one working castle gate. And it is guarded by sixty men.

question: And our assets?
answer: Your brains, Fezzik's strength, my steel.

question: I'll say -- how do I find the Count? -- Once I do, how do I find you again? -- Once I find you again, how do we escape? --
answer: Don't pester him, he's had a hard day.

question: Right, right, sorry.
answer: Inigo.

question: What?
answer: I hope we win...

question: momentarily surprised, then taking off after him, leaving Westley and Fezzik to exchange curious looks and Rugen, running through a half-open heavy wooden door, shutting it and locking it just as Inigo throws himself against it. He tries again. No kind of chance. Fezzik, I need you --
answer: I can't leave him alone.

question: desperately pounding at the heavy door. He's getting away from me, Fezzik. Please. FEZZIK!
answer: I'll be right back.

question: And he's running, dashing through corridors and as he glances back --
answer: behind him, coming like a streak and --

question: flashing out of one room, down a staircase, picking up his pace. He pulls out a deadly looking dagger, with a sharp point and a triangular shaped blade, and sprints on and --
answer: closing the gap, closer, closer and he's down the stairs and heading into a dining hall and --

question: throwing the dagger --
answer: trying like hell to get out of the way, but no, and it sticks deep into his stomach, and he hurtles back helplessly against the wall of the room, his eyes glazed, blood coming from his wound. ... Sorry, Father ... I tried ... I tried...

question: shutting the door of the Honeymoon Suite, crossing quietly to the far wall where she sits at a table, opens a jeweled box, and takes out a very deadly looking dagger. She seems very much at peace as she touches the knife to her bosom.
answer: There's a shortage of perfect breasts in this world. It would be a pity to damage yours. lying on the bed. Yellin's sword is beside him. His voice sounds just fine, but he does not move.

question: Oh, Westley, darling. Westley, why won't you hold me?
answer: Gently.

question: At a time like this that's all you can think to say? "Gently?"
answer: Gently!!

question: And as this blow comes he's trying to use the wall for support in forcing himself to his feet, and it's not a roaring success of an attempt, but he does at least make some progress, and again he manages to parry the thrust, as this time Rugen's sword runs through his right arm. Again, Inigo doesn't seem to mind, doesn't even feel it.
answer: stepping back forj ust a moment, watching as Inigo continues to inch his way to his feet and then, just before the Count is about to strike again, Inigo manages a little flick of his own and Rugen hadn't expected it, and he jumps back, makes a little involuntary cry of surprise and

question: slowly pushing away from the wall. Hello. My name is Inigo Montoya, you killed my father; prepare to die.
answer: suddenly going into a fierce attack, striking with great power and precision for he is a master swordsman, and he forces Inigo easily back, drives him easily into the wall. But he does not penetrate Inigo's defense. None of the Count's blows get home. As the Count steps back a moment --

question: HELLO! MY NAME IS INIGO MONTOYA.
answer: No --

question: -- offer me money --
answer: -- yes --

question: -- power too -- promise me that --
answer: -- all that I have and more please --

question: -- offer me everything I ask for --
answer: -- anything you want --

question: Oh, Westley, will you ever forgive me?
answer: What hideous sin have you committed lately?

question: I got married. I didn't want to. It all happened so fast.
answer: It never happened.

question: What?
answer: It never happened.

question: But it did. I was there. This old man said, "Man and wife."
answer: Did you say, "I do"?

question: Well, no, we sort of skipped that part.
answer: Then you're not married -- if you didn't say it, you didn't do it -- wouldn't you agree, Your Highness?

question: Then you're not married -- if you didn't say it, you didn't do it -- wouldn't you agree, Your Highness?
answer: entering the room, staring at them. He pulls out his sword. A technicality that will shortly be remedied. But first things first. To the death.

question: No. To the pain.
answer: I don't think I'm quite familiar with that phrase.

question: I'll explain. And I'll use small words so that you'll be sure to understand, you wart-hog-faced buffoon.
answer: That may be the first time in my life a man has dared insult me.

question: lying there comfortably, his words quiet at first. It won't be the last. To the pain means the first thing you lose will be your feet, below the ankles, then your hands at the wrists, next your nose.
answer: gripping his sword, watching. -- and then my tongue, I suppose. I killed you too quickly the last time, a mistake I don't mean to duplicate tonight.

question: I wasn't finished -- the next thing you lose will be your left eye, followed by your right --
answer: -- and then my ears, I understand. Let's get on with it

question: Wrong! Your ears you keep, and I'll tell you why --
answer: And now he stops, and the look that was in his eyes at the wedding, that look of fear, is starting to return.

question: -- so that every shriek of every child at seeing your hideousness will be yours to cherish -- every babe that weeps at your approach, every woman who cries out, "Dear God, what is that thing?" will echo in your perfect ears. That is what "to the pain" means. It means I leave you in anguish, wallowing in freakish misery forever.
answer: doing his best to hide the fear that keeps building inside him. I think you're bluffing --

question: lying there, staring at him. It's possible, pig -- I might be bluffing -- it's conceivable, you miserable vomitous mass, that I'm only lying here because I lack the strength to stand -- then again, perhaps I have the strength after all.
answer: staring, eyes wide.

question: Have a seat. speaking to Buttercup as Humperdinck sits. Tie him up. Make it as tight as you like.
answer: entering, looking around. Where's Fezzik?

question: I thought he was with you.
answer: No.

question: In that case --
answer: Help him.

question: They rode to freedom. And as dawn arose, Westley and Buttercup knew they were safe. A wave of love swept over them. And as they reached for each other...
answer: What? What?

question: No, it's kissing again. You don't want to hear it.
answer: I don't mind so much.
